context: [1] Isoprene can be made from endogenous carbon sources, especially from the Calvin cycle  or from exogenous DOX (; ; Fig. 6). [2] The pathway for incorporating exogenous DOX into plastid isoprenoids has a surprisingly high capacity. [3] Rates of isoprene-d2 emission as high as 60 nmol mâˆ’2 sâˆ’1 were observed. [4] Because the label in DOX-d2 appeared in isoprene rather rapidly and faded out with a similar kinetics after consumption, it is likely that labeled isoprene emission is indicative of the rate of phosphorylation of DOX. [5] One may speculate that plants have an endogenous capacity to phosphorylate DOX since the latter may act as a transport molecule in the plant. [6] The phosphorylation is assumed to be catalyzed by xylulose kinase, and there are two genes for this enzyme in Arabidopsis. [7] In Escherichia coli this enzyme confers the ability for the bacterium to utilize the sugar lyxose, an epimer of Xyl .

llm_generation.summary: In this context, 2-methylbuta-1,3-diene (isoprene) is indirectly related to phosphorylation through the discussion of deoxyribose (DOX) and its incorporation into isoprenoids. The rapid labeling of isoprene emission suggests a link to the phosphorylation of DOX, which may be catalyzed by xylulose kinase. However, the relationship between isoprene and phosphorylation is not explicitly detailed, focusing more on the metabolic pathway involving DOX.
